job_title: Customer Service Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great pay and benefits with 9 to 5 hrs
cons: None that I can think of at the moment

job_title: International Credential Evaluator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: New CEO finally approved raising wages to be enough to live on in not overly-expensive areas Health insurance is some of the best available Lots of opportunity for overtime but it's never required Job isn't difficult if you have a basic grasp of English (and knowing other languages can help) You have to really try to get fired
cons: You have to try really hard to get fired, so enjoy lots of deadweight coworkers Company has a four day week but new CEO keeps scheduling important all-company meetings on Mondays or Fridays when half the company doesn't work and expecting people to just rearrange their lives to show up anyway You'll likely have senior coworkers who have no idea what they're doing but are still here anyway because no one gets fired

review_title: Easy Work, Low Pay, Crappy Upper Management
job_title: International Credential Evaluator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Halfway decent job if you wanna mess around and get an easy paycheck. Max 1 meeting a week. You could easily hold this and another remote job down at the same time.
cons: Upper management paid drastically higher than employees. CEO is awful. Management is outdated. They assign you a desktop for remote work. Paid hourly and make adults clock in clock out , no time sheet (rare for a job like this). You have to clock in and out for lunch, breaks, and at the start and end of the day, which means even when you finish your work for the day or hit quote for the month, you still gotta clock in and out to get paid. Some managers are huge sticklers on this too. Somehow classifies as a nonprofit yet is very much in a grey area and frankly has some predatory business practices with their customer base. I'd avoid working here if you can.

job_title: International Credential Evaluator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: - WFH -Autonomy during day to day work
cons: - Requirements demanded by CGFNS program agencies can be frustrating to deal with

job_title: Credentials Analyst in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Personal manager was lovely, upper management less so
cons: Ineffectual systems, slow to change to meet demands and employees pay for it

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I'd say the only pro is the remote work opportunity. In my experience, managers have been great to work with, but their hands are typically tied due to company politics and out of touch upper management.
cons:
- ridiculously underpaid to the point of disrespect to employees, especially given education requirements
- while there are career pathing opportunities, there is absolutely no room for growth and do not expect an increase in pay
- upper management is severely out of touch with employees
- there exists a prominent culture of fear
- starkly evident favoritism

job_title: International Credential Evaluator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Diversity and Professional, great team
cons: low pay according to the amount of work

review_title: Leadership Doesn’t Care, Doesn’t Listen, High Turnover
job_title: International Credential Analyst in Philadelphia, PA
pros: My team tries hard to meet the overwhelming expectations and demands levied both by our Applicants (many of whom are wonderful to assist) and by CGFNS leadership. Individual team cultures probably vary, but for my team at least, we do our best to support each other.
cons:
It’s a self fulfilled prophecy of failure. Team(s) try to meet quota, teams are understaffed or lack support staff, leadership (namely CEO and COO) come down hard, team morale falls, employees leave due to stress and low pay, productivity falls as a result, and repeat. 

Leadership does not listen to suggestions and feedback from team leaders and team members. Starting pay for an analyst is $16.50/hr - we live in a major city, we’re expected to do more than just analysis work (customer support, data entry). We’re not paid enough, we aren’t staffed adequately, and we suffer as a result.

I’ve already started looking for employment elsewhere. I had hoped that I could stay here long term, maybe make a career out of it, but at this point, the pressure and lack of sufficient pay doesn’t motivate me (or anyone) to stay longer than a year.

job_title: NNAS International Credentials Evaluator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: It does look nice on your resume. Decent benefits.
cons: High-Stress Environment Little to no advancement opportunity Low Pay

job_title: credentialed evaluator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Very good health and dental
cons: Very low pay and raise is like never

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The health benefits are good considering the low pay, many mid- level managers and directors care a lot about their employees, regular schedule, they allow most roles to work remotely during COVID
cons: The high level leadership treats employees terribly and finds any excuse to pay as little as possible. The International Credential Evaluators do the work that is most integral to the business yet they are payed between $15 - $18 an hour even though the role requires at least a bachelor's degree. The "data entry" and customer service roles are much more than that, and are extremely detail oriented and high pressure, but the pay is very low. There is basically no room for career advancement in these jobs no matter how good you are at them, unless you somehow stand out to the CEO. Usually the only ones who are able to be promoted are young and white. When people are promoted from low pay positions, they are usually very over qualified and still end up being underpaid because upper management frames it as doing them a favor. The work environment is very toxic because employees are overworked as much as possible, and upper management are often berated by the CEO in front of other employees. HR is not really functional.

job_title: International Credential Evaluator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: 4-day work week, good management, and work is very independent
cons: Work is very repetitive, not a lot of collaboration/communication between employees

job_title: International Credential Evaluator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Has a great work/life balance
cons: Definitely underpaid for the work that we do

job_title: Research Associate in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Co workers are friendly and helpful, working for a good cause, good pay and work from home
cons: Working remotely can feel a bit distancing from the work environment but I still prefer it from being in office right now

job_title: Applicant Navigator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: A diverse group of people to work with.
cons: Understaffed constantly and not worth the pay.

job_title: Credital Analyst in Philadelphia, PA
pros: You get an annual raise
cons: HR is a nightmare and they changed hours/schedule 3 times in during my employment

job_title: Credentialing Analyst in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The Health Benefits. Co-workers from all over the world
cons:
Racist culture: 
This company intentionally hires international staff. However, this is exploited when business guests visit the office. The CEO pressures non white staff to explain their hereditary background to strangers as a point to show off the company's diversity and his benevolence of "giving them a chance" He has frequently commented that immigrants work harder than any other person of color and will make these colleagues admit that they worked retail or at a restaurant before coming to CGFNS 

There is very few people of color in management positions. However, this company is known to hire young under-experienced white staff and push them to management rolls. Meanwhile leaving behind people of color working on advance degrees and years dedicated to CGFNS. It's obvious and quite sad seeing that upper management keeps a close eye on each person's resume. 

Noncompetitive Pay: 
You will see a 1-2 dollar difference in company rolls. which isn't fair to some of the rolls that have a research element to them. If you have to find a job, i'd advise to go into data entry. Generally the pay is about 10K- 15K under any other credential company.


Constant Goal Post Moving:
Nothing is good enough. Goals are inflated to impossible numbers. 

Turn over:
you will see a new face bimonthly

job_title: Credentialing Analyst in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
- Coworkers are nice and most of them are competent

- Work is very easy as long as you can read basic English

- Insurance is fantastic

- Direct managers are usually nice and will try and keep upper management off your back

- It's really hard to get fired so no worries
cons:
- Pay is way too low and the only possible increase is the once-a-year 3%

- Quotas are artificially inflated

- IT is largely incompetent and the system is often down for hours

- It's really hard to get fired so you're stuck with incompetent coworkers until they decide to leave

- Competent people will only stay until they find a better paying job

- Being promoted to management is more a threat than a reward

- If you try their career ladder, you'll be given more work (including being on call 24/7) at the same pay

job_title: Senior Customer Care Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The people here are amazing !!  Eager to assist and very welcoming !! Most jobs are easy as long as proper on-boarding (training) is given.  All jobs are M-F all shifts between 8a-6p .. Location is very accessible in University City Philadelphia
cons: Favoritism and Double Standards are a constant even when it comes to pay and job advancement.  Knowledge base doesn't matter Upper Management only advances upper level degrees Master's and up.  Immediate Managers are great when they aren't being pressured by Director and CEO to enforce outdated rules.  Micromanagement seems to be the way to go while issues that need fixing go unnoticed.  This job offers only company wide raises at Christmas Time.  Broken promises of staff morale building exercises are a constant reminder that you aren't a person just simply a body in a seat to push work around and not even benefit the customer.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Philadelphia, PA
pros: My direct supervisor is great. Everyone who works here is hired under the assumption that they want to help foreign educated health care professionals. They work hard and are dedicated to doing right by our applicants. It is, in that sense, an excellent work environment.
cons: Unfortunately, in every other sense, it's a terrible place to work - spearheaded by the micromanaging maniac that is the CEO. I would bet money on him having stock in our competitors, that's how determined he seems to be to flush this organization down the toilet. Management forces employees to work in a constant state of unpreparedness to meet inflated production goals. Set up to fail from the start, the worst part is how much the higher ups love to find their fall guy.

job_title: Data Entry Tech in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Management makes an effort to bring people together and bring nicer things to the company. My coworkers are friendly, for the most part.
cons: Despite management staff trying to organize events and whatnot, the employees here would prefer to come to work and then go home. No one really wants to be bothered with gatherings or holiday events. Not really much cohesion between people and guidelines in my department are rather blurry.

review_title: Low morale and lack of communication
job_title: Credentials in Philadelphia, PA
pros: My co-workers were all very nice.
cons: I was never trained because they were looking for other people to hire and then train us all together. After being essentially ignored for over a week with no tasks or training, I decided to leave.
